messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for April 18, 2018 - April 24, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-04-25T19:44:16Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-04-18T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-04-24T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20180425-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs. 
   
Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6 for the reporting period. The highest values of Kp=6 occurred during the synoptic period of 2018-04-20T06:00Z-12:00Z. This increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-04-19 (see notifications 20180420-AL-001 and 20180420-AL-002). The solar wind speed reached values of ~600 km/s on 2018-04-20 and 2018-04-21.  

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of coronal hole high speed streams around 2018-04-19 and 2018-04-22. Solar wind speed reached values of ~500 km/s on 2018-04-19 and on 2018-04-23, respectively.

The >0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2018-04-20T21:15Z and continued to be elevated for the entire reporting period. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream described above (see notifications 20180420-AL-003, 20180422-AL-001 and 20180424-AL-001).

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron flux on the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-04-25T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-05-01T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. There are two active regions currently visible at the surface of the sun that could produce some flare or CME activity. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the expected arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-04-26.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-04-24T20:54:33Z
## Message ID: 20180424-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2018-04-20T21:15Z (see notification ID 20180420-AL-003 and 20180422-AL-001). Electron flux has remained elevated throughout the past four days and is currently above the threshold of 10^5 pfu, with the latest crossing at 2018-04-24T19:00Z.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2018-04-19T23:30Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2018-04-20T21:15:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes: 



NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-04-22T21:00:46Z
## Message ID: 20180422-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

This is an update to the notification with ID 20180420-AL-003. Energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt continue to be significantly elevated. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux first exceeded 10^5 pfu starting at 2018-04-20T21:15Z, and remain above 10^5 pfu, currently around 165,000 pfu.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2018-04-19T23:30Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2018-04-20T21:15:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-04-20T12:37:14Z
## Message ID: 20180420-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Ongoing space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2018-04-20T06:00Z to 2018-04-20T09:00Z. 

The storm is caused by a high speed stream starting at 2018-04-19T23:30Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2018-04-20T06:00:00-GST-001.

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for April 11, 2018 - April 17, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-04-18T18:18:29Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-04-11T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-04-17T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20180418-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs. 


Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic period of 2018-04-11T00:00Z-03:00Z. This slight increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-04-09. Solar wind speed reached values of ~600 km/s on 2018-04-11.

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a couple of coronal hole high speed streams around 2018-04-11 and 2018-04-16, respectively. Solar wind speed reached values of ~600 km/s on 2018-04-12 and 2018-04-17.


The >0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2018-04-11T15:30Z and remained elevated crossing the threshold twice up to 2018-04-13. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream described above (see notifications 20180411-AL-001, 20180411-AL-002, 20180413-AL-001 and 20180415-AL-001).


The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 


Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.



##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  


CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed   

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-04-18T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-04-24T23:59Z


Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. There are two small active regions present on the solar disk that have some potential for flares or CMEs. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be moderate for the upcoming week due to the expected arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream on 2018-04-20.



## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-04-15T20:19:45Z
## Message ID: 20180415-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

This is an update to the notification with ID 20180413-AL-001. Energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt continue to be significantly elevated. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux first exceeded 10^5 pfu starting at 2018-04-11T15:30Z, remained above 10^5 pfu by 2018-04-13T19:26Z, and are currently elevated above 70% of the threshold, around 71,000 pfu.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by high speed stream starting at 2018-04-09T06:00Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2018-04-11T15:30:00-RBE-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-04-13T19:26:28Z
## Message ID: 20180413-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2018-04-11T15:30Z (see notification ID 20180411-AL-002). The electron flux continued to cross the threshold, with the latest crossing at 2018-04-13T19:05Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2018-04-09T06:00Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2018-04-11T15:30:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for April 04, 2018 - April 10, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-04-11T23:03:55Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-04-04T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-04-10T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20180411-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were no significant flares or CMEs.  

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.  The highest values of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2018-04-09T21:00Z-24:00Z and 2018-04-10T03:00Z-09:00Z.  This slight increase of geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-04-09. 

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period, but started to become elevated at the end of the reporting period due to the coronal hole high speed stream described above.  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed 

CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-04-11T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-04-17T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  There are no significant active regions visible on the solar disk.  The geomagnetic activity is expected to be moderate for the upcoming week due to the coronal hole high speed stream described above. Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp=5 for the synoptic period of 2018-04-11T00:00Z-03:00Z.  The greater than 0.8 MeV energetic electron fluxes at the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 was above the threshold of 10^5 pfu starting at 2018-04-11T15:30Z (see notifications 20180411-AL-001 and 20180411-AL-002).  


## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for March 28, 2018 - April 03, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-04-04T20:50:44Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-03-28T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-04-03T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20180404-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

     
Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs. 

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=3 occurred during the synoptic period of 2018-03-31T00:00Z-03:00Z. This slight increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the small coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-03-29. The solar wind speed reached values of ~480 km/s on 2018-04-01.  

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-04-01. Solar wind speed reached values of ~650 km/s on 2018-04-01.

The >0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt were above the threshold level of 10^5 pfu at the beginning of the reporting period at 2018-03-28T00:00Z that lasted several days. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACR at L1 around 2018-03-22 (see notifications 20180326-AL-001, 20180326-AL-002 and 20180328-AL-001). 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron flux on the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed   

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-04-04T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-04-10T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. There is only one active region currently visible at the surface of the sun that could produce some flare or CME activity. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the expected arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-04-08.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
